Expresses worry about the quarterback and Tidwell’s safety, showing awareness of the situation.
Does not immediately confront or aggressively push Tidwell about the contract, instead proceeding carefully.
Offers support to Tidwell by saying 'I'll see you in Arizona' and 'Take care, okay? You're my entire client roster.'
Expresses dedication by going to see Tidwell in person rather than calling.
Responds defensively and avoids answering Tidwell’s personal questions about his marriage at first.
Eventually opens up about his marriage and loyalty, showing some sincerity.
Proceeds carefully with client negotiations, showing patience and dedication by visiting Tidwell in person despite tension.
Fails to effectively communicate or defuse tension with Tidwell, resulting in awkwardness and emotional discomfort.
Shows self-awareness and emotional reflection when confronted about his marriage and personal dedication.
Challenges Tidwell honestly about his motivation, framing it as a conversation between friends.
Insists on blunt truth even though it causes offense and damages friendship.
Offers to still have dinner despite the tension, showing willingness to maintain connection.
Confronts Tidwell frankly about his lack of passion in his professional play, attempting a tough-love approach to motivate him.
Pushes a personal and professional boundary by mixing friendship with business in a blunt manner, resulting in Tidwell ending their friendship.
Sits quietly and attentively, watching the Tidwells' loving family interaction with apparent respect and admiration.
In hospital room, observes birth with Dorothy but appears mortified and emotionally reserved, not engaging or comforting.
Sits quietly, watching others experience emotional family moments without actively engaging or reflecting out loud.
Appears mortified and with dry throat when witnessing childbirth, indicating emotional discomfort but no evident loss of composure or decision-making.
Expresses concern for Ray's safety, hopes he doesn't get injured and feels responsible.
Encourages Dorothy to ask him about his thoughts when she wonders, showing openness.
Responds to Ray's intrusion by welcoming him warmly and playing with him despite other tasks.
Adlibs some salesmanship on Tidwell's behalf during a phone call.
Feels inadequate in a moment of personal vulnerability with Dorothy.
Immediately leaps into 'crisis mode' trying to help Dorothy when she reveals her mistake.
States he is not the guy who runs and that he 'sticks,' showing reliability.
Admits doubts about being built for intimacy but expresses unwillingness to give up.
Engages in an honest conversation about his emotional limitations, showing some sincerity.
Questions Dorothy about her new partner (Ray), showing concern and emotional vulnerability.
Immediately goes into crisis mode to help Dorothy and tries to take responsibility by saying he won't run and will stick around.
Engages in emotional and somewhat clumsy dialogue, revealing vulnerability and slipping out awkward phrases like '...my soul or something,' showing difficulty with intimacy.
Is direct and honest about his limitations ('what if I'm just not built that way?'), which shows self-awareness and some degree of emotional intelligence.
Continues to press on despite the conversation suggesting a likely breakup, demonstrating persistence but possibly lacking the skill to navigate the emotional situation well.
Moves to embrace Dorothy after hearing painful truths but she pulls away first.
Kisses sleepy Ray goodbye gently, saying 'Don't wake up...'
Defensively defends his mission statement, showing discomfort but not hostility.
Has nothing to say when Dorothy shares painful feelings, showing possible emotional withdrawal.
Jerry, a man who speaks for a living, has nothing to say when confronted with emotional truth.
Moves to embrace Dorothy in an attempt to connect, showing willingness to act despite emotional difficulty.
Defensively minimizes his own Mission Statement to himself, indicating a lack of confidence in his ideas.
Passes through airport security with a deadened, glazed expression showing emotional exhaustion but no active response.
Defends Tidwell from Bob Sugar's manipulative approach, telling Sugar to get away from his client.
Intervenes decisively and confidently to protect his client Tidwell from the rival agent Bob Sugar's manipulation.
Protects Tidwell from Sugar by telling Sugar to leave.
Expresses that he missed Tidwell, showing sincere emotional connection.
Watches game intently, analyzing plays on the monitor, showing close attention to detail and situational awareness.
Stares stunned and silent after Tidwell's brutal injury, showing shock and momentary helplessness.
Calls Marcee to inform her about Rod's injury, tries to calm her despite his own fear.
Sprints through stadium, talks his way past a guard, staying focused on the unfolding crisis.
Calmly tells Marcee to stay calm despite both of them freaking out, showing presence of mind and leadership in a crisis.
Yells 'DON'T TOUCH HIM!!!' at the field to protect Tidwell
Strains at the sideline, watching over Tidwell with concern
Yells 'DON'T TOUCH HIM!!!' to prevent trainers from moving an injured player prematurely, showing quick thinking and concern for safety.
Passively watches the situation unfold at the sideline without intervening further.
Casually thumps his heart twice, showing personal emotional connection to Tidwell's moment.
Sits down overwhelmed with emotion, head in hands, indicating sincere emotional response.
Watches Tidwell's spotlight moment in complete disbelief but does not interfere or detract.
Watches Tidwell's triumphant moment in complete disbelief and becomes overcome with emotion, sits down with head in hands.
Hugs Tidwell emotionally after the game, shares a moment of tears.
Allows Tidwell to take his phone and joyously share the victory moment with his wife, watches supportively.
Appears emotionally void and unable to manufacture joy despite success and recognition.
Surrounded by well-wishers and sportswriters, signaling return to success and star status by association.
Cannot manufacture genuine joy despite success, showing internal void and emotional disconnect.
Answers phone promptly and with anticipation during emotional moment, demonstrating attentiveness and engagement.
Signs the Mission Statement for a young agent and expresses affection by saying 'Tommy. I love you.'
He signs a copy of his Mission Statement for a young agent, indicating that his ideas have inspired others and he retains influence in the industry.
Feels a shiver and odd feelings while reminiscing, distracted and lost in thought about Dorothy, showing emotional preoccupation.
Sprints through the empty airport to catch the last flight out of town, showing determination and urgency in his actions.
Enters Dorothy's house despite tension, openly expresses vulnerability and love, insists on not being discarded by her.
Attempts a heartfelt, vulnerable confrontation with his estranged wife despite an emotionally hostile environment.
Acknowledges his own emotional uncertainty and admits to struggling verbally.
Confidently declares his love and desire to reconcile in a tense setting, demonstrating emotional courage.
Moves to Dorothy and embraces her, giving the room hope, displaying positive emotional connection.
Leans over to Marcee and says 'Take care, Marcee. We'll see you at the restaurant.'
Watches wonderously at the monitor before leaving, showing appreciation and reflection.
Responds quickly and somewhat dismissively to Ray's natural ability by saying 'Come on, Ray.'
Leans over to Marcee and speaks with calm familiarity and confidence at the end of a long journey, showing composure.
Observes with wonder and satisfaction the TV monitor with his success reflected, showing self-awareness and acknowledgment of achievement.
When Ray shows surprising talent, Jerry and Dorothy quickly avoid addressing it and do not encourage the boy, indicating avoidance of important issues and lack of readiness to deal with challenges.
